Brief Hospital Course:
PATIENT SUMMARY
=================
___ year old female, history of alcohol use and likely alcoholic 
cirrhosis who was recently hospitalized with alcoholic 
hepatitis, who presentd with failure to thrive, n/v in setting 
of resuming alcohol consumption.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
[]Noted to be severe malnourished, recommend vitamin D repletion 
with ___ IU vitamin D weekly x 8 weeks then recheck level 
(first dose ___, will continue for 7 more weeks through 
___
[]Patient given resources for relapse prevention, please 
continue to encourage patient to attend treatment programs
[]will need to complete hepatitis B vaccination as outpatient - 
received Heplisav ___
[]Patient's husband expressed that she has passive suicidal 
ideation but no plan to hurt or kill herself. Please continue to 
offer support, counseling, and medications as an outpatient in 
conjunction with addiction treatment.

Discharge MELD: 19
Discharge Weight: 52.07kg 114.8 Ibs
Discharge Cr: 0.4
Discharge Tbili: 3.3
Discharge INR: 1.7

# CODE: Presumed FULL
# CONTACT: ___ ___

ACTIVE ISSUES
=============
#Alcohol use disorder
#Concern for alcohol withdrawal
#Alcoholic hepatitis
#Nausea and vomiting
MDF of 32.7 on admission. The patient reports drinking around 
500cc vodka daily from last weekend until ___ after 
attending a wedding. Nausea and vomiting likely from recent 
alcohol use and alcohol hepatitis. No diarrhea to suggest 
norovirus. Full infectious workup was done(bcx, urinalysis, cxr) 
wnl, no ascites on RUQUS. Nutrition noted severe malnutrition. 
Social work consulted, patient accepted list of resources to aid 
in cessation. Placed on CIWA protocol and received Valium for 
some withdraw symptoms during hospital stay. In addition, she 
received Zofran for nausea while monitoring ECG for Qtc, as well 
as daily thiamine, Multivitamin and folate. Patient did not 
receive steroids given MDF<32 after admission.

#Likely alcoholic cirrhosis
Follows with Dr. ___. Previous work up negative for Hep B or 
Hep C. No positive autoimmune markers. No iron overload. Her 
cirrhosis was decompensated by ascites but now without ascites 
on exam and off diuretics. Continues to drink.
VARICES: no varices as of ___ ___). Not on 
prophylaxis
ASCITES: history of ascites and previously on 
Lasix/spironolactone but is now off diuretics given euvolemic 
status, RUQ US was done which showed no ascites
SBP: no history of SBP
NUTRITION: low sodium diet, nutrition consult
COAGULOPATHY: INR elevated to 1.7, received 3 doses oral vitamin 
K while in house
VACCINATION: received one dose of hepsilav ___, will be 
due for next dose as outpatient, is immune to hep a by 
serologies ___

#Normocytic Anemia
Admission hgb 7.8 --> 6.7 (although all lines down suggesting 
dilution) with no evidence of melena, hematochezia, or 
hematemesis. No varices on EGD at ___ ___. Likely in 
setting of alcohol use and cirrhosis. Haptoglobin slightly low 
at 20, however with normal LDH less concerning for DIC. Recieved 
1 unit pRBC on ___ with appropriate increase in hemoglobin. 
Normal iron studies, folate, and B12.

#Borderline prolonged QTC
Has been stable around 480, Qtc was monitored closely in the 
setting of administration of QTc prolonging meds such as 
ondansetron

#Vitamin D deficiency
Started 8 weeks of Vit D 50,000 units on ___.

#Coagulopathy
Received 3 days of oral vitamin K while inpatient without 
improvement in INR

summary: Dear, Ms ___ You were admitted to the hospital because nausea, vomiting after drinking alcohol You were given medications to stop your nausea and vomiting. You were also given medication to prevent you from withdrawing from alcohol. You were seen by the social worker who gave you resources to stop drinking. You improved and were ready to leave the hospital. You must never drink alcohol again or you will die. You need to call one of the rehab facilities on the sheet given to you by social work to go to either intensive outpatient rehab or inpatient rehab to stop drinking. Please enroll in AA and try out a couple different meetings to find one that works for you, and work with your primary care doctor to determine the best strategy to help you stay sober.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is an ___ yo female with HTN, HL, who presented to an OSH 
after 3 weeks of recurrent chest pain, and recent stress MIBI 
with anteroseptal area of reversible ischemia, now s/p cath with 
DES to LAD, ostial RCA and mid RCA.
.
# CORONARIES: Pt required 3 stents on cath.  Pt clearly had CAD 
and needed to be optimized with medical manamgement.  We started 
pt on plavix and lisinopril, and increased her zocor and aspirin 
doses. We continued her home dose of atenolol. 
.  
# PUMP: Pt has some mild crackles at the lung bases bilaterally 
on admission exam, but otherwise no s/sx of volume overload.  
Echo showed EF of 60%.  Continued to monitor I/O's and daily 
weights, but patient's lung crackles remained stable and she had 
no SOB throughout her stay.  Did not diurese pt on this 
admission.
.
# CHEST PAIN: Pt had chest pain s/p cath with 3 stents placed.  
Pt's CK's trended upwards, which interventional attending felt 
was likely due to emboli that travelled to smaller vessels 
during the cath, but that there was nothing to treat, and we 
should continue our current medical management.  As EKG did not 
change, he was less concerned about in-stent thrombosis which 
would cause tombstone/ST-elevations on EKG.  
.
# RHYTHM: Pt has been in sinus bradycardia since has been on the 
floor, continued her home dose atenolol.  
.  
# HTN: Pt reports that her BP "never goes below 160".  She was 
on HCTZ at one point, but "it made me urinate", so she stopped 
it. We put pt on her home dose of atenolol and started 
lisinopril 5mg QD.  Pt's BP well controlled on nitro gtt, and 
remained in the 130's after nitro gtt D/C'd.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. atenolol 12.5mg QD
2. zocor 20mg QD
3. ASA 81mg QD

summary: You were seen in the hospital for recurrent chest pain. You were originally scheduled for a non-emergent cardiac catheterization, but you had an episode of chest and arm pain that brought you to the hospital emergently. You underwent a cardiac catheterization ___ where you had 3 stents placed. You continued to experience chest pain after the cardiac cath was placed, so we did repeat EKG's all of which showed no change from previous ones. We monitored the results of your blood tests, and had many consults from the interventional cardiologists who assured us that the chest pain was not worrisome and you were alright to go home with your EKG and blood work results as they had been.

History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with HTN who presented to her 
PCP with fatigue, dry cough, and RLE edema, was send to 
___ for CTA after D-dimer returned at >3000, was found to 
have a large uterine mass with pelvic adenopathy and possible 
liver/lung mets, and was transferred to ___ for evaluation by
GYN and ___. 

For the past month, she has had a non-productive cough, malaise, 
fatigue, fevers, and night sweats. She has lost about 7 lbs in 
the past year despite a stable appetite. She has some dyspnea on 
exertion as well. She a skin lesion on her abdomen which has 
been present for about ___ years but she developed a new one in 
the
last few months. No vaginal bleeding, hematuria, hemoptysis, or 
melena/hematochezia. No vaginal discharge or vaginal lesions. 

She noticed swelling in her RLE for the past few weeks. No calf 
tenderness. She had ___ which was negative for 
DVT. No chest pain or palpitations. No focal weakness or loss of

Overall, she just feels profoundly fatigued.

Physical ___:

GENERAL: Alert, NAD, breathing room air comfortably
EYES: Anicteric, PERRL
ENT: OP clear, mucous membranes slightly tacky

sounds present.

Pertinent Results:

LFTs wnl

___ Labs (___):
WBC 13.2
H/H 8.2/27.1
Plt 360
Na 139, K 4.3, Chl 106, HCO3 23, BUN 28, Cr 1.7

IMAGING:

CT Read from ___: 
1. Heterogeneous uterus with focal region of hypoattenuation 
along the posterior fundus is concerning for malignancy. 
Differential considerations include endometrial and 
leiomyosarcoma.
2. Multiple ill-defined hypodense liver lesions and extensive 
retroperitoneal, predominantly right pelvic, and bilateral 
iinguinal lymphadenopathy are concerning for metastasis.
3. Additionally, a lobulated, exophytic cystic and solid lesion 
along the anterior abdominal wall may also represent a cutaneous
metastasis.
4. Multiple pulmonary nodules, measuring up to 5 mm bilaterally.
5. Cholelithiasis.

Duplex US RLE:
1. No evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the right lower 
extremity veins.
2. Suspicious, prominently enlarged right inguinal lymph node 
measuring 6.5 x 3.5 x 3.3 cm.  Correlate with malignancy 
history. FNA is recommended.

CXR Pa/Lat: IMPRESSION:  No acute cardiopulmonary abnormality.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with HTN who presented to her 
PCP with fatigue, dry cough, and RLE edema, was send to 
___ for CTA after D-dimer returned at >3000, was found to 
have a large uterine mass with pelvic adenopathy and possible 
liver/lung mets, and was transferred to ___ for evaluation by 
GYN and ___.

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS:

# Suspected pelvic malignancy with metastases - imaging 
concerning for endometrial carcinoma vs. leiomyosarcoma with 
extensive lymphadenopathy (involving the pelvic, inguinal, and 
retroperitoneal chains) and possible metastases to the lung and 
liver. No evidence of pelvic malignancy on gynecologic / rectal 
exam done by gyn team. Oncology recommended targeting the left 
inguinal lymph node for biopsy due to its accessibility and also 
for diagnostic yield. 
 - ___ consulted for LN biopsy; discussed with ___ patient 
underwent LN biopsy by ___ on ___. Oncology (Dr. ___ 
___ follow up results outpatient and coordinate 
appropriate care.
- Uric acid level elevated and per Oncology recommendations she 
was started on allopurinol. 

# Acute Kidney Injury
-Baseline Creatinine unknown, but creatinine at ___ was 1.7 
improved to 1.0 with IV fluids.  No clear cause of volume 
depletion.  

# Iron deficiency microcytic anemia - acute on chronic / 
subacute iron deficiency anemia for which patient is already 
taking iron pills at home. Hemolysis workup here reassuring 
though with mild elevation in uric acid level for which she was 
started on allopurinol. She was transfused 1U PRBC on ___ given 
concern for symptomatic anemia as patient c/o ongoing fatigue 
and mild dyspnea on exertion. Her Hgb improved from 7.8 to 8.9 
after 1 unit of packed red blood cells which is also reassuring 
and no concern for active bleeding at this time. She will resume 
home dose of daily iron pills after discharge and follow up with 
her PCP for ongoing management of her chronic iron deficiency 
anemia. Could consider IV iron infusions down the line depending 
on iron stores. 

#SIRS
-Fever and tachycardia without localizing signs or symptoms of 
active infection, with negative culture results from urine and 
blood testing. Fever likely inflammatory/noninfectious in 
setting of malignancy and as long as continues without 
localizing symptoms of shortness of breath / cough, diarrhea or 
dysuria, can manage supportively with anti-pyretics. 

# Skin lesions
Violaceous cystic lesions in suprapubic region, one of which has 
been present for ___ years and the other just a few months. 
Unclear if this is related to her suspected malignancy. Advised 
to follow up with PCP and consider outpatient dermatology 
referral. 

CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS:
# HTN - continued home amlodipine 10 mg daily
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY 
2.  Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:

RX *allopurinol ___ mg 0.5 (One half) tablet(s) by mouth Daily 
Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY  
3.  Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO DAILY

Home with Service

Uterine Mass, Suspected pelvic malignancy with metastases
Microcytic, Iron Deficiency Anemia
Acute Kidney Injury

 
Discharge Condition:

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
summary: You came in to the hospital because you were having swelling in your leg. We did an ultrasound which did not show signs of a clot in the leg, but we did see an enlarged lymph node in the groin area which is probably causing swelling because of a blockage in the lymphatic drainage system from the enlarged lymph node. We did also find a tumor in your uterus and this looks concerning for cancer (metastatic gynecologic malignancy, likely leiomyosarcoma v. uterine carcinoma), but we won't know exactly or what the definitive origin is until the results from the biopsy come back. You had a biopsy done of this lymph node on ___.

Brief Hospital Course:
#. Diabetic ketoacidosis:  
Anion gap at presentation to ED was 17 with glucose level of 
approximately 700. Patient denied any enciting illness prior to 
start of his ketoacidotic episode. No fever or chills. Denies 
diarrhea. In the ED UA was negative for signs of infection. No 
acute process on admission CXR. Patient was complaining of some 
chest tightness in the ED and he had an EKG in ED with question 
of Q waves in III and aVF, but no ST or T changes seen. 
Unfortunately, no prior EKG for comparison. As his father had 
history of early demise from MI, we decided to ___. He had 
three negative sets of cardiac enzymes and no telemetry events. 
We discharged him on aspirin 81 mg and recommended outpatient 
stress testing. Patient received Q2H figersticks once arriving 
to floor with values of 251, 184, 166, 122, and 195 on night 
prior to discharge. He was given 24 U glargine insulin on night 
prior to discharge and put on humalog sliding scale. His 
preprandial sugar was 90 on morning of discharge. In the end, 
the diabetic ketoacidosis all likely related to having no 
insulin on night prior to presentation in setting of insulin 
pump failure. He was asked to restart subcutaneous insulin with 
24U of glargine per night and a humalog sliding scale per his 
prior regimen. He was going to trouble-shoot his pump with the 
pump company and consult with his primary care physician prior 
to restarting the insulin pump. His hemoglobin A1C was 8.1% 
during this hospitalization.

#. HCT drop:  
HCT at presentation was 46.2 and fell to 34.0 on morning of 
discharge. This in setting of rehydration with over 5L of fluid, 
though still a significant drop. Patient denied hematemesis, 
hematochezia, melena. His HCT was rechecked prior to discharge 
and was found to be 37. Patient had negative stool guaiac on 
rectal exam prior to discharge. He was recommended to talk to 
his primary care physician about anemia ___ and potential 
colonoscopy.

#. Alcohol use:  
Patient reports large amount of daily alcohol intake; however, 
denies intake in last two weeks as he gave up alcohol for Lent. 
Denies ever having symptoms of alcohol withdrawal. He was 
monitored, but showed no signs of alcohol withdrawal in his 
short hospitalization.
 
Medications on Admission:
1) Humalog insulin via pump
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
2. Insulin Glargine 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: ___ (24) 
units Subcutaneous at bedtime.
3. Humalog 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: as directed units 
Subcutaneous four times a day: Please administer according to 
your prior sliding scale regimen.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary:
1) Diabetic ketoacidosis
Secondary:
2) Diabetes, type I
3) Anemia

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable vital signs and stable hematocrit of 37
summary: You were admitted to the hospital with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is caused by a lack of insulin in your system. You can be made more susceptible to DKA by infection or heart attack; however, you showed no signs of infection and we ruled out a heart attack with three negative sets of labs. We would recommend that your primary care physician check ___ stress test to look at the health of your heart since you have diabetes and your father suffered from heart disease at a young age. You also had some evidence of a low red blood cell count (anemia). You did not appear to have any blood in your bowel movements, but you should work with your primary care physcian to further ___ this anemia. You should take 24 ___ (lantus) insulin each evening. You should administer humalog insulin prior to meals according to your prior sliding scale regimen. You should start taking an 81 mg aspirin daily to protect your heart. This is available over the counter at any pharmacy.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old male s/p MVC rollover.  He was taken 
to an OSH where he had a CT ___ which revealed a C4 
transverse process fracture, C6 facet, pedicle, and lamina 
fractures, and C7 pedicle fracture for which he was transferred 
to ___.  On HD1, the patient had a CT Torso which showed a 
large left renal subcapsular hematoma. He was admitted to the 
Trauma/Acute Care Surgery service for further medical 
management. 

On HD1, Orthopaedic ___ Surgery was consulted.  No surgical 
intervention was necessary and he was placed in a cervical 
collar which is was instructed to wear for 8 weeks. 

His hematocrit was trended and remained stable.  His creatinine 
was also elevated to 2.7 on admission and was monitored.  His 
PCP was called and his baseline creatinine was reported to be 
1.5.  Given his creatine was downtrending, the elevated creatine 
was attributed to his recent traumatic left renal injury and 
will be reassessed as an outpatient. 

On HD3, he received an MRI of his Mediastinum and Lung to 
evaluate the 3.9 cm well-circumscribed anterior mediastinal mass 
which was noted on his CT Chest.  The mass was most likely a 
benign thymic cyst, but, because contrast was not used due to 
elevated creatinine, a follow-up MRI was recommended.  

The remainder of the ___ hospital course is summarized by 
systems below:

Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout 
hospitalization; pain was managed with oral pain medication once 
tolerating a diet.

standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.

Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization. 

GI/GU/FEN: The patient tolerated a regular diet. Patient's 
intake and output were closely monitored.

ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none.

HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs 
of bleeding, and he remained hemodynamically stable. 

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and ___ 
dyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled. The patient worked with Physical Therapy who 
recommended his discharge to home with outpatient physical 
therapy services. The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

STUDIES:
----------
___ CT C-SPINE W/O CONTRAST: No fracture or prevertebral 
soft tissue edema. Minimal anterolisthesis of C7 on T1, likely 
degenerative, though clinical correlation advised. 

___ CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST: No acute intracranial process.

___ CXR: Satisfactory positioning of left chest wall 
pacemaker generator, right atrial and ventricular leads with no 
pneumothorax. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ F with history of two prior likely embolic strokes without 
clear etiology, also with HTN and HLD, who presented to the ED 
s/p syncopal event and developed sinus arrest with return of 
electrical activity and circulation without inrevention, likely 
sick sinus syndrome.   
   
# Sinus Arrest: Most likely sick sinus syndrome given abrupt 
pause in sinus rhythm on Tele. Tele without prolonging PR 
interval to suggest vagal event prior to this episode. 
Additional QRS complexes appear normal without AV dissociation 
or prolongation and QRS is narrow without bundle branch blocks. 
No escape rhythm suggests additional conduction disease. 1:1 
conduction of P waves also indicates AV node conducting 
normally. A dual-chamber ICD was placed without complications. 
She will take another two days of Keflex after discharge to 
complete post-pacemaker placement prophylaxis.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ year old man with HTN, HLD and Mantle Cell 
Lymphoma who presented C6 D19 of R-bendamustine with fever. 

#Fever. Mr. ___ reported a temperature measured at home on 
___ of 102. He was not neutropenic (WBC 2.1, ANC 1.48) and had

was negative. He had a chest X ray that was negative for 
infiltrates. Blood cultures showed no growth for 72 hours. He 
has aluminum staples in his gut from a prior partial colon 
resection, but otherwise has no foreign bodies. He also has a 
history of EBV viremia but < 200 copies EBV detected in blood. 
He was given vancomycin and cefepime on admission, but the 
vancomycin was discontinued  the morning after admission as he 
had been afebrile had no lines. Cefepime was continued for 24 
hours and then transitioned to PO ciprofloxacin for 24 hours. 
Cipro was discontinued on discharge. He was afebrile for the 
entirety of his hospital stay.

in his left wrist and was found to have a superficial vein 
thrombus of the left cephalic vein by ultrasound. This was 
treated with warm compresses and was improving at discharge.

R-Bendamustine. He was receiving acyclovir prophylaxis.

downtrend as expected during admission.

admission. Simvastatin was held and repeat liver enzymes in the 
morning had normalized so simvastatin was restarted with no 
further abnormality in liver enzymes.

summary: You came in because you were having fevers. Due to the chemotherapy you are receiving for your lymphoma, your body has more difficulty fighting off infections so we gave you antibiotics and tested you for common sources of infection. We did not find a source of infection. We stopped the very broad IV antibiotics and switched you to an antibiotic that comes in pill form (called ciprofloxacin). You did not have any fevers for 24 hours after this change was made and were generally feeling better and more energetic, so you were discharged. You do not need to take antibiotics once you leave the hospital. You should continue to take the medications you were taking at home. You also had a swelling in your left wrist. We did an ultrasound of your arm and found that you have a blood clot in one of the superficial veins of your arm. This was improving by applying hot compresses. You should continue to do this at home as long as the swelling bothers you.

Mrs. ___ is an ___ yo primarily ___ female 
who presented to the ED on the day of admission for evaluation

that this problem first began several months ago when some lower 
extremity swelling was noted, R>L. She was treated emperically 
for this with furosemide although it sounds like that did not 
help much. She was then started HCTZ, apparently both for her 
swelling and also for HTN. She developed some dehydration on 
this and was transitioned to lisinopril. Shortly thereafter, 
which was around one month ago, the patient noted the 
developement of a number of tiny red spots on her lower 
extremities. She discussed this with her PCP and was taken off 
all medications; per the patient's son, there was some concern 
for vasculitis. Some of these spots progressed however, and she 
developed a focal area of erythema, several centimeters in size, 
on her RLE. This eventually further deteriorated into a frank 
wound. She was seen in the ___ ED on ___ for this, was 
diagnosed with cellulitis, and was treated with seven days of 
Keflex. She took this medication and it apparently "quieted 
things down a bit," however the wound did not fully resolve and 
in fact has progressed of last.
.
Today, the patient and her son sought evaluation because of 
continuation and progression of her leg symptoms. She was having 
some difficulty ambulating at home due to mild leg pain. Also, 
notably, the area of the wound is extremely itchy. The patinet 
denies any fevers or chills.

summary: You were admitted with swelling and skin breakdown of your legs, mostly on the right. We believe this is likely due to leaky valves in your legs veins. Your primary care doctor can confirm this with a special ultrasound, although this may not be necessary if your legs improve with treatment. Please try to keep your legs elevated whenever you are resting. We have provided you with a prescription for compression stockings which you should wear every day; this helps keep excess fluid out of your legs. You can also use a topical emollient cream such as Aquaphor or Lubriderm which will help improve your skin integrity and decrease itching.

# Mediastinal Mass: unclear based on imaging whether mass 
present in anterior, middle or posterior compartment. Concerns 
for anterior mass including thymoma, teratoma, lymphoma and 
thyroid tissue. Concerns for middle compartment would be 
lymphadenopathy. Given stability of mass size and tracheal 
deviation from CXR in ___, unlikely to be lymphoma,

as this would not alter management given likely indolent nature

surgery and patient's PCP. AFP and B-HCG pending for evaluation

secondary to mediastinal mass. Patient started on benzonatate, 
guaifenisen, and acetaminophen.  Will continue to treatment 
symptomatically. Discharged with rx for tessalon perles.  Pt was

summary: You were admitted to ___ because of pain in your abdomen and nausea and vomiting. You were diagnosed with pyelonephritis (infection of the kidneys that occurs because the urine is infected). Please finish a 14 day course of antibiotics for this. Also, you may take the medication pyridium for up to three days to help with symptoms of bladder spasm. I have also given you a prescription for medication for nausea in case you need something. You may also take tylenol with codeine for your back pain from your kidney infection. Your antibiotics reduce the efficacy of your birth control pills in their ability to prevent pregnancy; if you are sexually active for the rest of this pack of pills make sure that your partner uses a condom.

Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o F w/ a hx of depression, anxiety,

showed no evidence of visceral injury in the chest. There was no 
pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum. The patient was initially 
transferred to the TICU for pulmonary assessment and hemodynamic 
monitoring.  She did not require intubation.  After remaining 
hemodynamically stable, the patient was transferred to the 
surgical floor.

ventricular cavity size with low normal global systolic 
function. Mild mitral regurgitation. No pericardial effusion.

___. The patient received prn lorazepam to help manage 
the patient's anxiety.  The patient's occlusive wound dressings 
were removed and dry sterile gauze dressings were placed.  The 
patient's foley catheter was removed and she voided. 

The patient tolerated a regular diet. The patient's fever curves 
were closely watched for signs of infection, of which there were 
none. The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs 
of bleeding, of which there were none. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and ___ dyne boots were used during this 
stay and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

summary: You were admitted to the hospital following a drug overdose and four self-inflicted stab wounds to your chest. You were admitted to the Trauma Surgery service for monitoring. You had an ultrasound of your chest done in the Emergency Department that demonstrated a small amount of fluid around your heart that was not causing any abnormalities. You then had a formal echocardiogram of your heart that demonstrated no abnormal fluid around your heart or other abnormalities in heart function. You were evaluated by Psychiatry and it was determined that you would benefit from further care in an inpatient Psychiatry unit.

summary: You were admitted to the hospital for management of your abdominal discomfort and a workup to determine the cause of your changing drain output. Upon evaluation with CT imaging, it was determined that you had a large pelvic fluid collection consistent with an abscess; a collection of infected material in your abdomen. You were re-started on IV antibiotics and you received a drain that was placed in the fluid collection via radiologic intervention. The drain entered your abdomen via your backside. Two of your previously placed abdominal drains were removed during this admission; thus, you will return home with 1 drain exiting in your abdomen, and 1 drain exiting from your backside. A visiting nurse service will be helping you maintain your drains as they did previously.

Brief Hospital Course:
#Nausea, vomiting, constipation
Mr. ___ nausea was controlled with Maalox, metoclopramine, 
ondansetron, and prochlorperazine.  During his hospital course, 
he was increasingly able to tolerate both solids and liquids 
without nausea or vomiting.  CT showed thickening of the 
esophagus.  After EGD found esophagitis and gastritis, he was 
eating normally, without any discomfort.  He was started on 
omeprazole 40mg BID.  Depending on the results of the EGD 
biopsy, the patient may require endoscopic ultrasound for 
further evaluation of the esophageal wall thickening.  He had 
one large volume, soft bowel movement after soap ___ enema in 
the ED, and he did not have any additional bowel movements 
during his hospitalization, most likely due to reduced food 
intake.
.
#EKG changes and cardiac enzyme elevations
Admission EKG showed evidence of V4-V6 ST segment depression, 
and this evolved to V4-V6 T wave inversion later in the hospital 
course.  In addition, CK and troponin were elevated when they 
were checked during the first 3 days of admission, though the 
consistently high levels may be a result of poor renal clearance 
rather than continuing ischemia.  Cardiology and the care team 
thought that the EKG changes and cardiac enzymes did not require 
acute intervention, and there is some suspicion of Takotsubo 
cardiomyopathy.
.
#Hyponatremia
Admission serum sodium was 122, but patient was not symptomatic. 
 This was thought to be the result of low intake of sodium 
secondary to nausea and vomiting, combined with high fluid 
retention driven by ADH in response to hypovolemia.  Sodium was 
corrected with fluids during the hospital course.
.
#Diabetes mellitus type ___ managed Mr. ___ blood glucose using QHS glargine and 
Humalog sliding scale.  They felt that this was superior to the 
previous ___ twice a day regimen, and they recommended that 
the patient continue his 44U QHSglargine and Humalog sliding 
scale starting at 2 units for glucose 120-159, with 2 additional 
units for every 40 mg/dL glucose over.

summary: you came to the hospital after you had one week of nausea and vomiting after you ate. You also had constipation. You had low blood sodium levels, which improved after we gave you fluids. Your heart had some electrical signals and had elevated enzyme levels that showed it might not be getting enough blood, but the cardiology team felt that you were safe. You had a CT scan that showed some thickening of your esophagus and some gallstone. In the emergency department, you had an enema and passed a bowel movement. You later felt like you had less nausea, and you were soon able to drink liquids and eat solids without any discomfort. You misstepped and fell, causing your right big toe nail to separate. Podiatry cut your toe nail, and you had no pain afterward. You had an endoscopy, which showed inflammation of your esophagus and stomach. After the procedure, you were eating solids and liquids without any difficulty.

Ext: Warm without cyanosis or pallor. Mild extremity edema.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Upon Emergency Department evaluation, CT of the abdomen 
demonstrated ventral hernia and right adnexal mass. Acute Care 
Surgery was consulted for management of recurrent ventral hernia 
and OB/GYN was consulted regarding the adnexal mass. MRI of the 
abdomen and pelvis which demonstrated similar findings. 
Differential included benign and malignant causes. Patient was 
taken to the Operating Room in joint operation with General 
Surgery for management of hernia and OB/GYN for management of 
adnexal mass was planned. The right adnexal mass was identified 
as a tuboovarian abscess and was drained of purulent fluid. A JP 
drain was placed in the right adnexal region for management of 
pelvic free fluid. The ventral hernia was then closed with a 
second JP drain left in a subcutaneous fluid pocket.

The patient was started on IV antibiotics postoperatively. She 
was observed and diet was slowly advanced. When JP drain output 
had diminished, after discussion with OB/GYN, JP drains were 
discontinued. Postoperatively patient had a rise in serum 
creatinine and diminished urine output. Urine electrolytes were 
consistent with prerenal dysfunction and patient was managed 
with IV hydration. When Cr remained, 2.0 for several days, 
nephrology was consulted. Renal ultrasound demonstrated no 
hydronephrosis. It was felt that acute kidney injury was likely 
secondary to dehydration with accompanied postoperative toradol 
and ACE inhibitors. They recommended that patient's home 
lisinopril be discontinued. They also recommended that patient 
not receive home chlorthalidone and that she avoid NSAIDs.

By the day of discharge, patient's Cr had begun to decline, 
urine output was adequate and Foley catheter was discontinued. 
She was able to void spontaneously and it was felt that it was 
safe for her to return home. She was tolerating a regular diet, 
was ambulating well with a walker and needed O2 only 
intermittently (which she had used prior to discharge). She was 
discharged on PO antibiotics (levofloxacin and metronidazole) 
for a total of 2 weeks. She will follow up with her PCP, OB/GYN 
and ACS.

RELEVANT IMAGING:
CT Abdomen and Pelvis ___:  
"1.  Limited study given body habitus resulting in significant 
streak artifact. 
Ventral abdominal hernia, with small bowel loops up to 3 cm in 
diameter 
proximal to this (upper limits of normal), but no transition 
point or 
significantly dilated loops to suggest obstruction. 
  
2.  Large right adnexal 9 cm multilobular hypodense lesion has 
increased in 
size compared to the prior CT, and has been characterized by the 
prior MRI 
from ___ of this year as a hydrosalpinx. 
  
3.  In the left adnexa, posterior to the uterus, there is a 
6.4-cm 
intermediate density abnormality, appearing increased from prior 
CT.  I note 
that followup MRI pelvis has been previously recommended. I 
would recommend 
performing this at this time, given apparent change since 
previous CT. Please 
also note prior MRI recommendation for large bore MRI scan, 
potentially with 
sedation if patient requires."

MRI Abdomen and Pelvis ___
" Enlarging unilocular right ovarian cystic lesion now 8.8 cm 
without overtly 
concerning features.  Low-grade neoplasm is not excluded, but 
this could be a 
simple benign cyst, with reactive enlargement due to the 
inflammatory process 
within the left adnexa.  Continued follow up in 6 months is 
recommended if 
resection is not performed. 
  
Progressive left hydrosalpinx with some fluid complexity, mural 
hyperenhancement and surrounding edema.  A developing pyosalpinx 
is not 
excluded. 
  
Increasing free pelvic fluid, some of which appears loculated, 
representing 
either loculated ascites or inclusion cysts. 
  
Likely uterine adenomyosis, with nonspecific focal mucosally 
based area of 
hyperenhancement within the right cornua. 
  
Large umbilical hernia, containing multiple loops of small 
bowel."

Renal Ultrasound 
No hydronephrosis.

summary: You were admitted for nausea, vomiting, and lightheadedness. You did have some mild dehydration and were given IV fluids. You were evaluated by Endocrine; your labs were NOT consistent with adrenal insufficiency. We think that your nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may have been related to a viral gastroenteritis, a side effect of your psychiatric medications, or a stress response. In consultation with your psychiatrist, we decreased your perphenazine to 6mg twice daily. You should stop taking Seroquel You may advance your diet slowly as tolerated (try simple broths and lighter foods if feeling nauseated), but please keep well hydrated to avoid feeling lightheaded. Please note that your white blood counts remain low, probably related to your psychiatric medications. This puts you at higher risk of infection. We recommend that you wear a face mask whenever you go out in public, that you avoid sick contacts, and that you wash your hands frequently to prevent spread of infection.

summary: You were admitted to the hospital because a bacterial culture from your peritoneal fluid came back positive. You had no signs or symptoms of infection and it was thought that the positive culture may have been from contamination. You were not given antibiotics. Several sets of repeat peritoneal cultures were negative. You also had some low blood pressures while you were in the hospital. One of your medications, Geodon, can cause low blood pressure. Please talk to your psychiatrist to determine if there is an alternative medication that may cause less side effects. Please continue to take this medication until you speak to your psychiatrist.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was assessed in the ED by both Cardiology and 
Neurology.  ECG revealed sinus rhythm 64 bpm with prolonged AV 
Conduction, right bundle-branch block, left anterior hemiblock 
and subsequent ECG frequent VPBs.  His syncopal episodes and 
paroxysm of light-headedness were concerning for underlying 
conduction system disease.  Pacemaker was recommended, he was 
consulted by the Electrophysiology team who recommended 
placement of a pacemaker.  Additionally, because of his history 
of CVA, he was seen and evaluated by Neurology.  A head CT was 
performed and was negative for any acute infarction or 
hemorrhage.  Ventricles and sulci were normal in size and 
configuration.  Neurology recommended an updated carotid 
ultrasound as one had not been done for several years for 
comparison, results of which are pending at the time of 
discharge.  It was felt that the patient's symptoms were cardiac 
in nature and the patient elected to proceed with pacemaker 
insertion, understanding risks and benefits.  There were no 
intraoperative complications, the patient tolerated the 
procedure well and was placed on IV antibiotics while in house 
with a plan for three days oral antibiotics at discharge.  His 
surgical wound remained well approximated, with no signs of 
erythema, excess warmth, drainage or hematoma.  Surgical 
dressing consisted of gauze and Tegaderm which will remain 
intact for 72 hours.  A chest X-Ray was performed prior to 
discharge showing good lead placement and no acute process.  The 
device was interrogated and was operating appropriately.

Please see d/c instructions for activity precautions for the next 6 weeks. A neurologist evaluated you in the emergency room and did not feel that you had a stroke. The head CT scan was unchanged and the carotid ultrasound results are currently pending. Your symptoms were cardiogenic in nature and a pacemaker was successfully inserted.

summary: Postoperative Care: Do not expose recipient site to prolonged sunlight Follow instructions given for bandaging the grafted area to provide it with appropriate support during the healing process, and to prevent contractures even after healing is complete. Inspect site for healing and good circulation, as shown by healthy pink coloration. Keep the recipient site clean and dry. You'll need to use a plain (bland) oil product to lubricate the recipient site, since there are no functioning sweat or oil glands in a skin graft. Outcome A successful skin graft will result in transplanted skin adhering and growing into the recipient area. Cosmetic results may vary, based on factors such as type of skin graft used, and area of recipient site.

summary: You were admitted with right sided weakness after a fall. We suspected that this was caused by a seizure. You were found to have more inflammation around the covering of the brain on the left side, which likely caused the seizure and your weakness. We put you on a medication that prevents seizures. We performed multiple tests but without performing surgery we were not able to find out exactly what was causing the inflammation. One possibility for the inflammation was a disorder called amyloid angiitis, and we decided to presumptively treat you for this condition. You received five days of high dose steroids and will continue on steroids for another two months.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old otherwise healthy female who was 
seeing a urologist for symptoms of overactive bladder. She was 
started on empiric treatment for UTI with bactrim and 
subsequently developed a diffuse rash and fever. Her exam was 
consistent with a morbilliform exanthematous drug eruption, with 
the presence of painful vulvar erosions is concerning for early 
SJS. Dermatology was consulted, who recommended 5 days of 
prednisone 1mg/kg daily. Her lab results showed no signs of 
DRESS. Rash and labs were monitored overnight with interval 
improvement of her rash over 24 hrs. The pt was counseled on 
avoiding bactrim, sulfa products, and NSAIDs.

On her labs, the pt showed pancytopenia, likely secondary to 
bactrim. She should have her CBC with diff and LFTs checked on 
___ prior to PCP ___.

Pt also complained of dysuria, which is likely due to mucosal 
irritation of the urethra. Her urine culture was negative. 

Lastly, pt was advised to stop all unnecessary medications, 
including oxybutynin and fluconazole. Given that she has been 
taking her OCP for several years without reaction, she was not 
advised to stop this.

Transitional issues:
# follow up of pending blood cultures
# repeat CBC and CMP and f/u with PCP
# restart medications as deemed appropriate
# return to urologist for further eval of overactive bladder

summary: You were admitted to ___ for a severe rash. You were evaluated by the dermatology team, who felt that this is most likely a severe hypersensitivity reaction to Bactrim. You were prescribed prednisone which you will need to take for a total of five days (last day ___. For the rest of your life, you will need to avoid the medication Bactrim or any other "sulfa" containing drugs. Use caution when taking medicines from the family "non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs," as these are closely related to the sulfa group. NSAIDs include aspirin, advil, motrin, ibuprofen, naproxen, and aleve. The box will include NSAIDs as one of its ingredients.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo female with recent admission for mechanical fall who 
presents after a fall with brief LOC. The history was consistent 
with a true syncopal event. The long pro-dromal period (>10 sec) 
did not favor a primary cariac etiology. A vaso-vagal reaction 
versus orthostatic hypotension (dehydrated with BUN:Cr 30 on 
admssion) were considered most likely. However, there was no 
change in position or movement of the neck before the fall.
.  
1) Syncope: The patient did well while in house and had no 
further epidoses. Though there was no chest pain, an admission 
set of cardiac enzymes was nevertheless negative. An EKG showed 
NSR at 93bpm, LAD, TW flattening in III. Telemetry monitoring 
showed multiple PVC's. There were two traces suspicious for 
v-tach/fib, but on review these were artifacts (only seen in one 
lead). Echo had been carried out two weeks prior, and showed no 
systolic dysfunction or valvular disease. An exercise stress 
test with nuclear imaging showed no abnormality.
Given that the etiology of this event was not clearly defined, 
the patient was instructed to abstain from driving for six 
months, to which she agreed.
.
2)Carotid bruits: These were detected on exam. The patient was 
counseled as to the diagnostic options, ramifications, as well 
as potential medical and surgical management. She declined 
carotid u/s, stating that she would be unwilling to have 
surgery. ASA 81 was maintained. She was instructed that if she 
changed her mind about carotid u/s she should schedule with her 
PCP. 
.  
3) Cardiovascular: Patient did well on her home meds: lisinopril 
20, lovastatin 20, ASA 81. No changes were made.
.
3) Anemia: Her baseline appears to be in the high 30's, but she 
has been in the low to mid 30's since ___. There may have been 
some blood loss associated with her fall two weeks ago which 
could account for this. Fe, TIBC, ferritin, folate, were normal. 
B12 was low-normal, but without evidence of macrocytosis. 
Haptoglobin was slightly elevated, LDH was normal. Guaiac was 
negative. Patient was discharged with a multivitamin.
.  
4) Facial rash: Patient had a faint ___ rash on 
her forehead and cheeks which resolved after one day of lotion.
.
5) Neck/spinous process fx from previous admission. Rads had 
recommended outpatient MRI for further evaluation. This will 
require follow-up with her PCP. Patient had declined that as an 
outpatient, however. 
.
6) Code status: Patient confrmed her DNR/DNI status.  
.

Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY  
Aspirin EC 81 mg PO once a day  
Lovastatin 20 mg PO once a day

summary: You were admitted to this hopsital after a fall. We believe that this fall was caused by either a vasovagal response or dehydration or a combination of the two. We did tests to see if you had a heart attack, and these were negative. We also evaluated whether your heart had an abnormal rhythm, called an arrythmia, and we found no evidence of this as well. Finally, you had a stress test to see if your heart is receiving enough oxygen, which was without abnormality. Because we do not have a definitive diagnosis for your episode of fainting, we advise you not to drive for the next 6 months out of concern that you could have another episode. You should speak with your primary care doctor before you resume driving.

summary: You were admitted to ___ with abdominal pain and had an ultrasound showing you to have gallstones without evidence of acute cholecystitis (inflammation of the gallbladder). You also had a HIDA scan which was normal and did not demonstrate acute cholecystitis. The pain you had was likely reflective of chronic inflammation of your gallbladder or biliary colic (intermittent pain caused by gallstones). It is recommended you follow-up in the outpatient Acute Care Surgery clinic to discuss timing of an elective gallbladder removal surgery. You were resumed on a regular diet which you are now tolerating and your pain has improved.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with ___ CAD s/p CABG x 3 found at ___ to have 
a type B dissection with uncontrolled hypertension, transferred 
to ___ for further management. The patient reported urinary 
retention, which is new for him, that prompted him to seek care 
at ___. After multiple attempts at foley placement, a foley

was started for systolic blood

the ___ ED, the patient is a relatively poor historian when it

a doctor in ___ years then states he was at ___ 3 months ago 
for SOB, which resolved. He is also unable to remember the date 
of his CABGx3, and regarding an open inguinal hernia repair he 
cannot remember which side was repaired. He denied CP, SOB, 
abdominal pain or back pain, but does complain of cervical neck 
pain which is muscular in nature per patient. He complained of 
penile pain from the foley catheter in place. No neurologic 
complaints. 

While at ___, patient was seen by urology whom did not feel 
like there was any prostate involvement and recommended that he 
be started on 0.4mg Flomax and keep the foley in place for the 
next ___ days followed by a voiding trial. 

In terms of the dissection, we had an MRI/MRA taken to evaluate 
the Type B dissection and the read was an unchanged type B 
aortic dissection with the largest caliber at the 
thoracic/abdominal aorta junction measuring 4.7 cm. It was 
difficult to discern the true from the false lumen. However both 
of the lumina have good flow. The right lumen supplies the right 
renal artery, and the celiac artery 
partly. The left lumen supplies the rest of the intraabdominal 
branches the dissection flap does not move indicating a chronic 
nature.

Mr. ___ was admitted to the inpatient colorectal surgery 
clinic with complaint of abdominal pain and diminished output 
from his colostomy. A CT scan in the emergency department was 
reviewed and significant for: small bowel obstruction with 
dilated loops of small bowel and transition, air and stool seen 
in colon to level of LLQ colostomy, moderate amt of ascites, 
increased  left hydroureteronephrosis and delayed excretion of 
contrast from left kidney, may relate to infiltrating masses in 
pelvis, left greater than the right, thickening of the 
rectosigmoid with loss of adjacent fat planes, and osseous mets 
with concern for destruction of inferior right sacrum, 
underlying fracture could not be excluded. The patient was 
monitored closely. His laboratory values were stable. In the 
___ morning of hospital day one the patient reported passing a 
small amount of flatus from the colostomy and a small amount of 
stool. The patient's symptoms improved slightly and a 
nasogastric tube was not placed. Of note, after discussion of 
the patient's condition, a multidisiplinary team approach was 
thought best and palliative care nurse practitioner was 
consulted for symptom management and discharge planning, and 
radiation oncology for symptom management of the hip pain 
related to metastasis. The patient's outpatient oncology 
attending was involved in patient care decisions, the patient 
ultimately was recovering and the patient remained on the 
surgical service until discharge at the recommendation of the 
Oncology service. On hospital day three the patient was 
tolerating a regular diet, passing stool and flatus from the 
colostomy, and his pain was controlled with OxyContin and 
Dilaudid my mouth. The patient was ambulating with a cane and 
eager to return home. His discharge plan was coordinated with 
The attending oncologist. He was referred to Palliative Care as 
an outpatient however, the patient was hesitant. He was given 
all of the contact information. The outpatient oncology staff 
was notified of the patient's discharge and need for a follow-up 
appointment.

summary: You presented to us because your white blood count, particularly neutrophils, were low, and because you had evidence of CMV in your blood. We believe this is most likely due to a viral infection called CMV and some of your medications may also be contributing. We have discontinued INH, and you no longer need to take it unless it is recommended to you by the infectious disease team. We have started you on weekly injections called neupogen that will help increase your white blood count. Your father will do the weekly injections for you as we discussed. You were found to have a virus in your blood called CMV, and you are being treated with an oral medication called valcyte.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with history of substance abuse, presenting from OSH with 
heroin overdose.

# Respiratory failure: 
Secondary to heroin overdose with component of noncardiogenic 
pulmonary edema.  Received naloxone in the field with 
improvement in symptoms. Patient was easily extubated after 
arrival. He was persisently hypoxemic after extubation which was 
thought to be secondary to aspiration pneumonitis found on CT. 
There was no evidence of pulmonary embolism. 

# Fevers: 
Patient reporting history of ___ days fevers prior to 
presentation, found to have mild neutrophilic leukocytosis. Was 
given vancomycin/piperacillin-tazobactam/levofloxacin at OSH. An 
echocardiogram was performed to evaluate for endocarditis given 
drug use history, though no vegetations were identified on TTE. 
Blood cultures have remained negative. Other possible foci 
included an effusion identified on OSH CT C-SPINE. An MRI was 
performed to evaluate for abscess; this was not evident on 
imaging. Patient was discharged on short course of 
amoxicillin-clavulanate for aspiration pneumonitis/pneumonia.

# Heroin overdose: 
Patient with history of polysubstance abuse. During 
hospitalization, patient required clonidine, lorazepam, and 
hydromorphone to prevent agitation. Patient was unwilling to 
wait for social work evaluation.

Patient left against medical advise after demonstrating 
understanding of risks of leaving hospital prior to complete 
evaluation. He was provided with course of 
amoxicillin-clavulanate as above.

summary: You were admitted to the hospital for evaluation of your shortness of breath and wheezing. You were evaluated by the pulmonary team, social worker and wound care nurse. The pulmonary team recommends that you take lasix 40 mg a day to help reduce the fluid in your lungs. You were found to have low oxygen levels likely from the stress on your lungs from extra weight. This is called obesity hypoventilation syndrome. For this you were started on continuous oxygen. You were also found to have severe sleep apnea. You were started on bipap. With Bipap you improved. You will have a bipap delivered to your home tonight. It is important you wear this every night. As we discussed losing weight is extremely important. This would help alleviate many of your illnesses including diabetes, sleep apnea, and your need for oxygen. After discharge please call the medical weight management center at ___. Our nutritionist met with you and as we discussed it is important to eat ___ calories or less a day. It is also important to avoid concentrated sweets like soda. It is also important that you find a therapist to help you with your weight loss journey.

Brief Hospital Course:
#. Perioral lesions: Per patient, lesion started after sterile 
strips were taken off her face after the laminectomy. Based on 
the one-sided distribution of the lesions, the possibility of 
HSV was considered. Patient was treat with Acyclovir and 
discharged with medication to finish a 7-day course. Over the 
course of the hospitalization, the lesions improved and did not 
spread to another other area. Patient remained afebrile without 
leukocytosis on discharge. She was instructed to stop using the 
desonide and triamcinolone ointment obtained from her primary 
care physician.
.
#. Fevers: On admission, patient reported nocturnal fever up to 
100.3 in the 3 days prior to admission. Given her recent history 
of laminectomy and low-grade nature of her fevers, it was felt 
to be most consistent with post-operative fever. The Orthopedics 
service examined her surgical site, which remained 
clean/dry/intact and without signs of infection. Patient will 
follow up with them on discharge.
.
#. Aortic stenosis: Patient was asymptomatic throughout the 
hospitalization. She had plans to have aortic valve dilation 
soon. Her blood pressure ranged from 100-105/60-70, which per 
patient was similar to her new, post-catherization baseline. 
Furosemide was held throughout the hospital course and patient 
did not experience increasing lower extremity edema as a result. 
Patient was instructed to follow up with primary care physician 
and outpatient cardiology upon discharge. 
.

Echocardiogram revealed normal systolic function and no regional 
wall motion abnormalities. There was also a small effusion vs 
fat pad. D-dimer was negative. Most likely diagnosis is acute 
pericarditis - patient was started on ibuprofen and colchicine. 
Pantoprazole was started for GI protection. Other home 
medications were continued.

Transitional issues:
[] Patient to establish care with a cardiologist
[] Consider repeat TTE to further characterize pericardial 
effusion vs fat pad if symptoms persist
[] Consider changing anti-hypertensive to a calcium channel 
blocker if symptoms fail to improve, as this may also represent 
coronary vasospasm

summary: You were admitted for pericarditis. You were evaluated for chest pain and changes on your EKG. You underwent cardiac catheterization which revealed no significant blockages in the blood vessels of your heart. This is most likely caused by inflammation of the sac (the pericardium) that contains your heart, called pericarditis. This is treated with anti-inflammatory medications - ibuprofen and colchicine. The pain may persist for several weeks / months but should gradually improve. The main side effect of NSAIDs like ibuprofen is stomach upset and a risk of bleeding from the stomach. Be sure to take this medication with food.

summary: You were admitted because you had an abnormal heart rhythm during an exercise stress test. You were also noted to have heart failure. The hearts main function is to pump blood to your organs and the pumping function of your heart is reduced. You were started on heart healthy medications to help protect your heart and potentially regain some pumping function back after a period of time on the medications. These medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. Furosemide, also known as Lasix, will help you get off extra water weight. It is a diuretic. We aren't sure why your heart is weak but it might be from the abnormal heart rhythm. Metoprolol will also help prevent this heart rhythm abnormality. You underwent cardiac catheterization that did not reveal any significant atherosclerosis, or plaque in your arteries.

We do not yet know the exact cause of your colitis but it is most likely due to a condition known as inflammatory bowel disease. Distal descending colon, biopsy:
- Colonic mucosa with focal acute inflammation, nonspecific 
finding.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ presenting with one week of constipation and abdominal pain. 
CT scan showed an area of thickening and stranding around the 
sigmoid consistent with sigmoid colitis, and what appeared to be 
a partial large bowel obstruction. ___ noted to be 14. She was 
otherwise hemodynamically stable and in no acute distress. She 
was admitted for bowel rest, IV fluids, IV antibiotics. 
Gastroenterology was consulted. The patient was prepped and went 
for sigmoidoscopy / colonoscopy with biopsies taken. There was 
no evidence of an obstruction. There was evidence of colitis. 
After the colonoscopy, the patient was doing well. 

Diet was progressively advanced as tolerated to a regular diet 
with good tolerability and she continued to have good bowel 
function. The patient voided without problem. During this 
hospitalization, the patient ambulated early and frequently, was 
adherent with respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and 
actively participated in the plan of care. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this 
stay.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged home without services. 
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan. She was given a prescription to complete a 
course of antibiotics and had follow-up scheduled with GI.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with a hx of cocaine abuse, 
alcohol abuse and tobacco use who preseted with left sided chest 
pain most consistent with a musculoskeletal origin 
(costochondritis) however pericarditis, cocaine chest pain, ACS 
and PE remain on the differential.
.
1) Chest Pain: His pain was reproducible with palpation and was 
relieved by rest which was most consistent with a 
musculoskeletal origin. He was most tender at the left border of 
the sternum making costochondritis the most likely etiology. He 
noted having subjective fevers and chills which were concerning 
for pericarditis however EKG did not reveal any changes 
consistent with pericarditis and there was no rub on exam. He 
has no hx of CAD, and his only risk factor is smoking; 
furthermore, EKG and cardiac enzymes were unremarkable despite 
ongoing symptoms for several weeks and  therefore less likely to 
be ACS. As for PE, there was no evidence on EKG to suggest right 
heart strain and the pain has been present for 3 weeks making it 
less likely. He does admit to using cocaine but not thought to 
be consistent with vasospasm.  He denies any immediate use. EKG 
did not reveal any ischemic changes.  The morphine was 
discontinued on the floor in favor of ibuprofen.  

2) Substance abuse: He admitted to using cocaine last 3 weeks 
ago although further review of records from ___ 
within the past week showed a positive urine tox screen for 
cocaine.  As above, his pain was not thought to be consistent 
with cocaine-induced vasospasm, but we discussed how cocaine can 
have serious cardiac effects.  He also has significant alcohol 
use and reports a history of withdrawal, including seizure.  He 
reports trying to cut down.  Pt was not interested in treatment 
programs at this time.  

3) Alcohol Abuse: He was on a CIWA protocol however he did not 
require any valium. He showed no evidence of withdrawal during 
admission.

4) Dispo: Patient discharged and outpatient plan explained, but 
he left before receiving his paperwork.

summary: You were admitted for chest pain which has been present for several weeks. The pain does not appear to be coming from your heart. Your presentation is consistent with a musculoskeletal inflammation. You should benefit from a short course of anti-inflammatory pain medication. During your admission, you noted that you had recently used cocaine. We strongly recommend that you abstain from using cocaine in the future. Although the chest pain you experienced does not appear to be from your heart, cocaine can cause significant damage to your heart, including heart attack. You would benefit from consistently meeting with a primary physician who can help you find appropriate resources. We also strongly recommend that you abstain from alcohol use. As sustained alcohol use can lead to nutritional deficiencies, we have prescibed several vitamin supplements. Smoking cessation would also greatly reduce your risk of multiple health problems, including heart attack. It will be important for you to establish care with a primary care provider.

Brief Hospital Course:
1. Dizziness, bradycardia
The cause of the patient's transient dizziness in bed was not 
clear, but suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo. 
In any case, her symptoms did not recur in hospital. The 
occurrence of her symptoms while lying in bed also raised the 
question of arrhythmia. Her implanted event monitor was 
therefore interrogated by the EP service. There was no obvious 
arrhythmia to explain her symptoms. She did have episodes of 
probable AV block versus SA block, but no pauses>3 seconds; 
these episodes appeared to be all asymptomatic. We discontinued 
her diltiazem due to concern for it causing bradycardic 
episodes. 
A TIA could not be excluded. She will continue aspirin, and 
follow up with her PCP for further evaluation of dizzy episodes 
should they occur.

2. Hypertension
The patient's valsartan was increased after her diltiazem was 
discontinued. Her blood pressures in house were adequately 
controlled with systolics in 130's with this change. Her 
valsartan can be titrated up further as needed as an outpatient. 
Would suggest holding off on nodal blocking agents if plan to 
add a second antihypertensive.

summary: You were admitted for an abnormal heart rhythm called Atrial Fibrillation. You were successfully cardioverted and will be anticoagulated with a blood thinner named ___ for at least 4 weeks. You will need to have your blood checked regularly in order to make sure that you are on a safe dose, as different patients can respond differently. The levels of this medication can be altered by different foods and medications, so try to eat a consistent amount of green leafy vegetables daily and tell any physican prescribing you a new medication that you are coumadin. Your cardiologist, Dr. ___ follow up on your results and adjust the dose accordingly. Alcohol is one of the underlying causes of atrial fibrillation. It is strongly advised to reduce alcohol consumption to prevent recurrence of this abnormal heart rhythm.

Brief Hospital Course:
An ___ man presents from home with progressive weakness 
and cough, found to have fever, radiographic evidence of 
pneumonia and positive urinalysis.  
.
# Pneumonia: Etiology was a combination of community-acquired 
pneumonia and aspiration pneumonia due to Zenker's diverticulum 
(see below). Patient treated with ceftriaxone and azithromycin 
initially, then switched to po levofloxacin and will finish a 
10-day course after discharge. Blood cultures were no growth to 
date at the time of discharge. Urin legionella negative.  
Patient initially had fevers and 3 liters oxygen requirement. 
Both improved prior to discharge. 
.
# Zenker's diverticulum: There was concern for aspiration 
pneumonia based on radiographic evidence on admission. Video 
swallow and esophagram performed which showed Zenker's 
diverticulum leading to regurgitation and subsequent aspiration 
of food. Patient and family aware of the risks of food intake. 
He was instructed to crush all pills. Patient will follow-up 
with primary care doctor after discharge for definitive surgical 
treatment. 
.
# Chronic renal failure: Per primary care doctor and urologist, 
patient has history of chronic renal failure from overflow 
incontinence, with baseline Cr 1.5 - 2. Here, his Cr ~1.8 with 
good urine output through Foley catheter. He maintained good 
urine output throughout. 
.
# Anemia: Chronic issue and had stopped coumadin recently due to 
supratherapeutic INR. Iron studies showed low iron but normal 
ferritin, most likely a response to acute illness. Hct stable 
throughout. 
.
# Atrial fibrillation: Continued on home Aspirin + Diltizem 
regimen. Patient had one episode of Afib with RVR to 150s which 
resolved spontaneously. 
.
# Positive urinanalysis: Most likely from chronic colonization. 
Patient asymptomatic. At suggestion of outpatient urologist, 
Foley was not exchanged. Urine culture here showed <10,000 
organisms.  
.
# Diarrhea: Resolved spontaneously. No leukocytosis. 
.

summary: you were transferred to the ___ ___ because you were coughing and felt weak. We found that you had a pnuemonia and gave you antibiotics to treat it. Your kidney function improved after we kept you some IV fluids. Your blood count was low and we gave you some iron to help with that. You had a video swallow test which showed that you have an outpouching of your esophagus ("Zenker's diverticulum"). Food gets stuck in this pouch and you sometimes aspirate it into your lungs, which is most likely why you have been getting pneumonias. It is important to discuss surgical repair of your diverticulum with your primary care doctor.

summary: You were admitted to ___ with lower extremity swelling and redness. You had a CT scan of your abdomen and an ultrasound of your lower extremities to rule out blood clots and venous obstruction. You got one dose of antibiotics in the emergency department because of concern that you might have an infection, but after close exam and lab tests it does not appear that you have an infection. The test of your heart function show that your heart is pumping very well and this is unlikely to be contributing to your swelling. It is possible that the swelling is related to you decreased mobility secondary to your hip surgery. You were started on a medication called "lasix" to help your body get rid of the extra fluid in your legs. You were also given special stockings to help with the swelling. Please continue to take the lasix once daily, to use the stockings, and to elevate your feet when you can. Physical therapy worked with you while you were here and you should continue to see your physical therapist at home.

MRI Head: Right frontal signal abnormality with a central 
portion of 
restricted diffusion is not typical for an infarction and is 
predominantly 
involving the white matter. The restricted diffusion could favor 
infiltrative lesion with high cellularity such as lymphoma or 
encephalitis. Differential diagnosis could also include PML if 
there is history of immunocompromised status. 

PET CT Scan: 1. Right frontal infiltrative white matter 
predominant leison 
without significant increase in FDG avidity as compared to 
background 
physiologic gray matter uptake, not necessarily excluding 
neoplasm in the 
differential consideration. 2. FDG avid retroperitoneal 
adenopathy largest 
conglomerate aortocaval in location, but also involving 
periportal and 
retrocaval stations.  

CT Torso: 1. Suboptimal contrast bolus. Given this, no evidence 
acute injury to the chest, abdomen, or pelvis. 
2. Large retroperitoneal mass which likely represents lymph node 

conglomerate. Several other prominent nodes surrounding the 
right kidney and porta hepatis concerning for malignancy. 
3. Bibasilar opacities consistent with atelectasis and 
possiblyaspiration. Small amount of material in the trachea 
consistent with aspirated contents. 
  
CT Cspine: 1. No acute fracture or dislocation. 
2. Gas tracking along the retropharyngeal space,as above. 
Findings could 
relate to a traumatic intubation. However, other injury to the 
trachea or 
esophagus cannot be completely excluded on the basis of this 
study. 
  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ M with hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia who 
sustained an MVA after not being able to stop from turning left. 
Later at the scene, EMS noticed him to have a GTC with left gaze 
deviation. For airway protection, he was intubated in the ER and 
started on a fentanyl/versed drip, keppra loaded and 
subsequently been seizure free. He was successfully extubated 
and transferred out of the ICU. A routine C-spine CT scan 
performed to clear his C-spine identified the presence of air 
tracking in the retropharyngeal space, and for this, he received 
7 days of broadspectrum antibiotic therapy (IV). 

A head CT scan at the ___ ER showed the presence of a right 
frontal mass, which was subsequently further characterized on 
MRI as being FLAIR hyperintense and non-contrast enhancing, and 
on the differential diagnosis includes primary CNS lymphoma 
versus a metastatic lesion or gliosis/glioma of some type. At 
the same time, a trauma protocol torso CT scan identified a 
series of nodes in his retroperitoneum concerning for 
malignancy. The oncology, general surgery and neurosurgery teams 
were consulted. While oncology recommended an excisional lymph 
node biopsy over a brain biopsy, the nodes in his abdomen were 
thought to be in too delicate a location (between his IVC, aorta 
and duodenum) to be easily sampled without a a high risk open 
laparotomy. An LP was performed, and on cytological analysis, he 
was found to have hypercellular atypical lymphocytes that could 
occur with a number of benign and malignant processes. Flow 
cytometry analysis on that sample is still pending. 

Ultimately, it was decided to discharge the patient home with 
follow up as noted below. The patient was instructed to come to 
the neurology clinic if he had not been contacted by the ___ 
department directly for a brain biopsy admission. On discharge, 
he was afebrile and hemodynamically stable. His neurological 
exam was normal, including tests of frontal lobe dysfunction. He 
only complained of a sore throat, otherwise he was largely well 
appearing without any other specific complaints. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Synthroid 25ug daily 
Atorvastatin 20mg daily

summary: You were admitted to the ___ for an evaluation of your seizures. We found a large mass on the right side of your brain that likely led to your seizures, and that likely is a malignancy/cancer. Additionally, we observed a series of enlarged lymph nodes in your abdomen that is concerning for cancer. You were intubated (breathing tube placed) for one day, and you received antibiotics for a total of seven days for some trauma in your throat that you sustained during that process. We performed a lumbar puncture on your spine which did not show an obvious infection. We are awaiting a formal pathological investigation of that fluid. You were seen by numerous specialists, including members of the general surgery, neurooncology, neurology and neurosurgery teams.

summary: ___. As you know, you were admitted with lower extremity weakness, back pain, and urinary retention. You had extensive workup for your symptoms - including MRI L-spine and Lumbar x-ray in extension/flexion positions. These results did not show any anatomical or distinct cause for your symptoms. There was no impingement of the spinal cord. As a result, the neurosurgery team (Dr. ___ did not recommend a surgical intervention. You were noted to have a distended bladder from a urinary retention. A foley catheter was placed with significant output of urine. You will be discharged with the foley, and we recommend that you follow with the urologist at ___ to do a urodynamic testing to assess the cause of the urinary retention. You also had a urinary tract infection (Enterococcus). For this, you were placed on ampicillin (IV) and then subsequently an oral antibiotic - Augmentin. This should be completed for an additional 6 days.

summary: You were hospitalized here for treatment of your left leg infection. You were thought to have a continued cellulitis that had failed outpatient oral antibiotic therapy. You also had significant drainage and crusting of the leg wound on the back of your left leg. You were seen by Plastic Surgery, and your wound was treated topically with silver sulfadiazine and wrapped with Kerlex and Ace wrap twice daily, which helped with debridement of the wound. Your infection was treated with IV antibiotics, and your blood cultures showed no growth (final reads pending on discharge). The Infectious Disease specialists were consulted to help decide which antibiotics you would need at home, and they have recommended two different oral antibiotics for your cellulitis.

Your diarrhea improved significantly while you were in the hospital. Since we were unable to get a stool sample to test for specific bacteria, we were ultimately unable to diagnose the cause of your symptoms. Brief Hospital Course:
The patient yesterday was at the parking office, and then had a 
syncopal episode after he had a coughing spell. The patient was 
transferred to ___ initially where he had a CTA of the chest 
done which was negative for PE however showed that there was 
only a 4mm opening of the trachea. The patient was transferred 
to ___ for further care.

Syncope: The patient had syncope secondary to a 
vasovagal/possible hypoxemic episode after a coughing fit. It is 
unlikely to be seizure as the patient states that he has had 
seizures in the past that presented differently. He states that 
he had chest pain after the syncopal episode however he stated 
that this was secondary to CPR performed at parking office after 
his syncopal event. Ishcemia is also unlikely given that he had 
a stress test done on prior admission which was negative for 
ischemia. The diagnosis was confirmed when the patient had two 
additional syncopal episodes while in the presence of the 
interventional pulmonary fellows who agreed that the patient 
would need to be taken to the OR for stenting and debridment so 
the patient does not have any further episodes of syncope.

Cough: The patient had a cough which is likely secondary to the 
SCC of the larynx that the patient has. He was given 
guaifenesin-dextromethorphan

Tracheal Narrowing: The patient has laryngeal SCC which has 
narrowed the trachea to 4mm per the report from ___. 
Interventional pulmonary service was called and agreed that 
since the patient is poorly compliant that he would likely need 
to have a stent placed. Since he had lunch, he was added onto 
the OR schedule for tomorrow. However while the IP fellow was in 
the room, the patient had a coughing fit and syncopized. At this 
time the decision was made to transfer to the patient to the ICU 
and take him to the OR for an emergent intervention. IP placed a 
stent following coughing fit and procedure went well. He did not 
have any complications from his procedure. Patient maintained 
excellent ventilatory status during and after procedure, and 
felt well overnight. He was transferred to the floor where he 
was observed for an additional 24 hours. Subsequently the 
patient developed some hemoptysis consisting of blood tinged 
sputum. Initially the sputum was red colored, however 
subsequently it became brown colored. IP fellow was made aware 
of this and saw the sputum and agreed that he was ready for 
discharge. The patient states that at discharge his breathing 
was normal and much better than it has ever been. He was not 
complaining of shortness of breath or chest pain. The patient 
was made aware of the importance of following up at ___ for 
cyberknife treatments.

Fever: Overnight on ___ the patient had a temperature of 
100.4. A chest x-ray was checked, urine analysis was checked 
both of which were negative. Blood cultures were drawn and sent 
off to be followed up by his primary care doctor. The patient 
also did not have any additional fevers after the low grade temp 
of 100.4. 

Increased Creatinine: The patient had creatinine checked on a 
daily basis and it remained stable throughout his 
hospitalization. The patient will follow up with his primary 
care doctor for this.

summary: Syncope/ Transient Loss of Consciousness Syncope or fainting is a common problem caused by inadequate blood flow to the brain. There are many serious reasons for fainting, including internal bleeding, irregular heartbeat, and diseases of the heart muscle or valves or circulation. Other causes include diseases of the central nervous system, medications, low blood sugar, or dehydration. Vasovagal Syncope is the most common cause of syncope and can occur in healthy people at the sight of blood, hearing unexpected news, or while experiencing pain During your stay in the hospital, we did not find an immediately life-threatening cause for your loss of consciousness. Rarely, serious symptoms can develop later.
