Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo female with central hypoadrenalism presumed secondary to 
lymphocytic hypophysitis, initially admitted for abdominal rash 
but subsequently kept in the hospital for recurrent episodes of 
syncope. Her hospital course will be briefly reviewed.

1) Abdominal rash: She was initially referred to the Emergency 
Department out of concern for zoster, and admitted to the floor. 
The rash was not consistent with herpes zoster. She was treated 
symptomatically with antihistamine agents, with interval 
improvement. 

2) Recurrent syncope: While on the floor, she experienced 
recurrent episodes of syncope, once while transferring from a 
wheelchair to the bed, and another event 
while attempting to move her bowels. She described repeated 
similar events at home for many years. Repeated orthostatic 
vitals were within normal limits, despite reports of dizziness 
with standing. She additionally described a complex set of 
symptoms, including nausea, anorexia, recent weight loss, 
generalized weakness, and lightheadeness, present over the past 
several months. She was placed on a trial of stress dose 
steroids, without symptomatic improvement, arguing against 
adrenal insufficiency playing an important role in her above 
symptomatology. The endocrinology service was consulted for 
additional advice, and recommended rapidly tapering her steroids 
to baseline. Additional laboratory evaluation was advised to 
evaluate for possible hypothalamic dysfunction. Most of these 
blood tests are pending at the time of discharge. They 
additionally recommended repeating an MRI of her pituitary in 
the out-patient setting, and consideration of autonomic testing. 
Please refer to their consultation note available in OMR. 

3) Retrosternal pain: While on the floor, she additionally 
complained of retrosternal pain, possibly related to gastritis 
in the setting of systemic steroids. Proton pump inhibitor 
therapy was initiated.

She was evaluated by physical therapy, and discharged home with 
services. She was able to ambulate with a walker in her room. 
She was also provided with a wheelchair prior to discharge. 
While the exact etiology for her debilitating symptoms remains 
unclear, this represents her baseline, and we felt comfortable 
discharging her with close out-patient follow-up.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecologic oncology service for a 
large pelvic mass and rectal bleeding. 
 
Upon arrival to the hospital, her BP was 216/100. Patient was 
asymptomatic at the time. EKG showed normal sinus rhythm. She 
was given 25mg hydralazine and placed on telemetry. The medicine 
service was consulted regarding her hypertensive urgency. They 
recommended 5mg Amlodipine QD and 25mg Q6 PRN hydralazine for 
SBP >160. Given continued elevated BP, medicine consult team 
decided to change regimen to Diltiazem 60mg Q6H with PRN 
hydralazine for SBP >180. They also recommended no further 
testing needed to optimize patient prior to surgery. Patient is 
to follow up with her PCP outpatient for HTN. 

The GI service was consulted regarding her rectal bleeding. They 
performed an EGD and colonoscopy on HD#2 and found an esophageal 
hiatal hernia, duodenal bulb ulcer, mild diverticulosis. Biopsy 
of ulcer was positive for H. pylori. Patient was then started on 
14 day course of prevpac. 

Of note, on the night of HD#1, patient was had a code blue for 
loss of conscious while on the toilet after drinking the bowel 
prep for her GI procedure. Patient returned to conscious after 
~10 seconds. Stat labs, EKG, telemetry, and CXR were ordered and 
were assuring. Patient was given two 500mL bolus of LR and 
symptoms improved. After careful evaluation, event was 
attributed to a likely vagal response while using the restroom. 

Patient then underwent exlap, TAH, BSO, pelvic mass resection 
for serous cyst adenofibroma. Her post-operative course is 
detailed as follows. Immediately postoperatively, her pain was 
controlled with IV dilaudd. Her diet was advanced without 
difficulty and she was transitioned to PO tramadol and 
acetaminophen. On post-operative day #1, her urine output was 
adequate so her Foley catheter was removed and she voided 
spontaneously. 

By post-operative day #3, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

summary: You were admitted to the gynecologic oncology service after being seen in clinic for a large pelvic mass in the setting of recent weight loss and rectal bleeding. We consulted the gastrointestinal physicians and they scoped both your upper and lower gastrointestinal tract. During the procedure, they found a hiatal hernia and an ulcer. They took a biopsy of the ulcer and it showed a bacterial infection. We started you on treatment for this infection while you were in the hospital. You will continue to take these medications to complete a 14 day course. The gynecology oncology service then performed the procedures listed below.

viral syndrome.  Initial suspicion for meningitis in the ED and 
patient given ceftriaxone and vancomycin prior to arrival to the 
medical floor (pt refused LP).  Clinical suspicion for menigitis 
was very low by the time of the patient's admission to the 
floor, so antibiotics were discontinued.  Malaria was also 
entertained given prior traveling history and lack of 
prophylaxis, but smears were negative times four.  Pt did not 
receive any pretrip vaccinations.  Time line of presentation 
inconsistent with dengue.  Typhoid fever and yellow fever also 
thought to be less likely.  Full infection workup, including 
blood cultures, urine analysis, chest radiograph, liver function 
tests, and infectious labs - including viral hepatitis 
(A,C,D,E), EBv, toxo, CMV - were all negative.  With supportive 
care and fluid, the patient's fevers resolved and  symptoms 
significantly improved by hospital day three.  Patient was 
discharged home with PCP follow up.
.
#Tachycardia: On admission patient was tachycardic to the 120s 
which responded well to IV fluid boluses.  EKG consistent with 
sinus tachycardia.  Differential for tachycardia included fever, 
infectious process, anxiety, and hyperthyroidism.  TSH was sent 
which came back as 0.031 with T4 of 7.9 which suggested 
subcllinical hyperthyrodism for which patient will follow up 
with his PCP for further management.  On the day of discharge 
patient's heart rate had decreased to normal ranges of ___. 
.
Transition of care:
Pending Labs: Blood Cultures with no growth to date.
Patient will follow up with his PCP on ___ for evaluation 
of any remaining symptoms he may have as well as for management 
of his subclinical hyperthyrodism.
 
Medications on Admission:
Tylenol PRN headaches
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

Home

1. Viral Symdrome
2. Sub clinical Hyperthyrodism
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
summary: You were admitted because you were having headaches, shaking chills, fatigue, for two days. Your symptoms were most likely because of a viral syndomee. We did many lab tests for different viruses as well as for malaria which all came back as normal. You were afebrile for over 24 hours without medications and your symptoms significantly improved with conservative therapy with pain control. Most of your symptoms should resolve fully between ___ days. You can take tylenol as needed for pain. You should avoid drinking alcohol while you are taking tylenol. In the hospital you also had thyroid test which suggested that you may have sub clinical hyperthyroidism.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a long standing 
history of gastroesophageal reflux disease who presented with 
melena. She underwent an endoscopy which demonstrated a small 
ulcer in the duodenum.

# Melena: Found to have melena in the emergency room and also to 
be tachycardic. She received IVF with improvement in his heart 
rate.  GI was consulted in the emergency room and recommended IV 
PPI BID and was scheduled for an EGD the following day.  This 
revealed a small hiatal hernia, scarred duodenum, and a small 
bleeding ulcer without a visible vessel in the pyloric channel - 
which was injected with epinephrine. The duodenal bulb was 
deformed which was suggestive of previous ulcers that had 
scarred. A biopsy was not taken due to concerns for bleeding. 
Her diet was slowly advanced as tolerated. Her hematocrit 
trended down during her hospitalization. It was 37.7 on 
admission and decreased to a low of 25.9. She did not require 
transfusions. She had several black stools during the 
hospitalization, likely from her previous bleed.  She was 
transitioned to PO PPI on discharge.  She was discharged with 
instructions to have a HCT drawn as an outpatient for followup 
and with an appointment to follow up with her PCP shortly after 
discharge.  

# H pylori; Ms. ___ reported a history of indeterminate H. 
pylori serologies. Her tests here also came back equivocal 
(negative is < 0.75, positive is > 1.0, patient's serology was 
0.85). Given the extensive scarring of her duodenum, she was 
started on triple therapy.

Full code (confirmed with patient) throughout hospitalization

summary: You were seen at the ___ for melena (dark blood in your stools), nausea, and vomiting. In the emergency department you were noted to have blood in your stools. You were given intravenous fluids and medications to help reduce the acid in your stomach. You were transferred to the floor and the following day received an upper endoscopy (an EGD or esophagogastroduodenoscopy) to look for a source of bleeding in your esophagus, stomach, and part of your small intestine. A bleeding ulcer was found in your duodenom (small intestine) and epinephrine was injected to help stop the bleeding. You were noted to be anemic on transfer to the floor from loss of blood. Your anemia was stable during the last two days of your admission. This should be followed up with your outpatient primary care physician to make sure no more bleeding is occurring. You also received a blood test for H. pylori, a bacteria that can cause ulcers. The result was equivocal.

Brief Hospital Course:
Assessment/Plan:
___ y.o woman with no PMH who presents with headache and fever 
found to have aseptic meningitis.

#aseptic meningitis
#headache (likely combination of post LP and meningitis) ?NSAID 
related
#fever
Pt was treated for a presumed viral meningitis. CSF gram stain 
and cx negative. She was given CTx and vancomycin in the ED 
which were discontinued on the floor given negative CSF. She was 
treated with acyclovir until HSV and VZV were negative. GIven 
that she continued to spike fevers despite supportive care, 
consulted ID who recommended a more intensive work up that was 
unrevealing by the time of discharge.  She did develop some 
abdominal pain mostly in the ruq.  LFTs were slightly elevated, 
and multiple additional serologies were sent and were 
unrevealing at the time of discharge.  Transvaginal, abdominal, 
and ruq ultrasounds were negative for pathology.  Pt's continued 
headache could have also been due to post LP headache and/or 
NSAId induced.  Symptoms improved.  On the day of discharge pt. 
had been afebrile for over 24 hours, and was strongly desirous 
of going home.  Her pain was controlled, she was tolerating po 
intake, ambulatory, and voiding on her own.  Her LFTs were 
stable, with ALT of approx 100, without any elevation in 
bilirubin.  This was felt to be part of a likely viral syndrome. 
 Doxycycline was started emperically at ID's recommendation over 
concern for possible anaplasmosis (test pending at discharge), 
and this was well tolerated.  The plan is for her to return home 
and we will follow up on the results of multiple pending 
serologies.  She should see Dr. ___ this week for repeat 
evaluation including a repeat test of LFTs, CBC, and Chemistry 7 
(see below, and this was explained to patient). 

.

.

atropine and begin chest compressions. Per the attending note 
from OSH, ___ chest compressions were performed at which point 
patient regained consciousness with a HR in the ___.  EKG showed

Patient was transferred to ___ for further evaluation.  In the

received 4 mg morphine and Maalox and was admitted.
.
Of note, patient has had vasovagal syncopal episodes in the past 
and frequently gets woozy when he donates blood. He has no h/o 
CAD, anginal type symptoms, no smoking hx, no HTN, 
hypercholesterol, or DM.  There is no family history of sudden

the heart is probably normal in size. The mediastinal and hilar

Brief Hospital Course:
# CHEST PAIN:  no associated ischemic sxs such as nausea, 
diaphoresis, radiation, shortness of breath, to corroborate ACS. 
 However, episode of pulseless arrest lasting 10 seconds at OSH 
immediately after administration of SL NG was concerning for R 
ventricular or inferior wall ischemia.  At time of admission to 
___, patient had HR in mid to high ___ with SBP 110-120.  His 
EKG showed no ischemic changes.  He was followed on telemetry 
overnight and his cardiac enzymes were cycled.  Troponins were 
negative x3. Telemetry showed sinus brady with rate 55-65.  On 
HD 1 patient intermittently complained of chest pain, a 
sensation of substernal "squeezing" as he described it.  EKGs 
were repeated and all negative.  Due to concern of RCA ischemia, 
a right-sided EKG was performed.  This showed no ischemic 
changes.  Patient has no coronary risk factors; however, due to 
the repeated episodes of chest pain not entirely suppressed by 
PPI and antacid therapy, and the 10 second pulseless arrest at 
OSH in response to NTG, there is concern of right-sided 
ischemia.  He will schedule for outpatient exercise stress 
testing.  He is discharged on baby aspirin daily.
.
Chest pain symptoms were most consistent with GERD.  While in 
house patient was treated with omeprazole and Maalox.  He is 
being discharged on both meds.
.
A CXR performed in the ED was reviewed with radiology and there 
was no sign of rib fracture.  Patient did intermittently 
complain of pleuritic type pain over his left chest (different 
in location and quality than the squeezing sensation described 
above) likely ___ the chest compressions he received at OSH.
..  
# SYNCOPAL EPISODE:  The history was c/w vasovagal syncope. 
Telemetry strip from OSH showed severe sinus bradycardia (HR 12) 
with longest pause of 10 seconds.  As described above, there was 
concern that NTG may have precipitated the sinus pause.  
Cardiology was consulted re: sinus arrest in setting of chest 
pain and administration of a preload reducing agent.  They felt 
that the sinus pause was most consistent with a severe vasovagal 
episode (rather than right-sided ischemia).  Further history 
revealed that patient had once collapsed in front of a judge 
during a court case and that he had a history of getting woozy 
around blood draws.  To be sure there is no underlying coronary 
ischemia, he will undergo stress testing as outpatient.
..
# H/O ASTHMA:  he was treated with albuterol nebs prn.

summary: You were hospitalized for chest pain. We were concerned about your heart rate and the temporary loss of consciousness you experienced at ___. We have looked at your electrocardiogram and measured enzymes in your blood and do not believe your chest pain is related to your heart. The temporary loss of consiousness you experienced at ___ was likely a normal physiologic response to the anxiety of having your blood drawn. We have started you on one new medication for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which we believe is the cause for your chest pain. You have taken the medicine before. It is called omeprazole (Prilosec). We would also like you to start taking one baby aspirin (81 mg) each day to help prevent cardiovascular disease.

Brief Hospital Course:
# Nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhea: Patient presented to the 
emergency department with a somewhat chronic history of lower 
abdominal pain, nausea and diarrhea. According to the patient 
the symptoms have been becoming somewhat worse and has 
associated weight loss. She was unable to tolerate p.o.'s the 
time of her admission. It is unclear the etiology of her 
symptomatology. We obtained a right upper quadrant ultrasound 
that showed cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis. We 
also obtained a CT scan of the abdomen the only demonstrated 
diverticulosis without any other acute pathology. The patient 
received IV fluid, antiemetics. Her symptoms improved 
significantly after IV fluid administration. The patient seemed 
to respond well to Compazine. The patient will be discharged 
home with a prescription for p.o. Compazine as needed for 
nausea. She is also encouraged to followup with her primary care 
physician for possible referral to a gastroenterologist for 
further workup.

#Acute renal failure: The patient presents to the hospital with 
a creatinine of 2.6 her baseline of 1.2 approximately one month 
ago. Likely etiology is significant dehydration in the setting 
of poor p.o. intake with concurrent use of thiazide diuretic and 
ACE inhibitor. The patient received multiple liters of IV 
crystalloid in the emergency department and on the medicine 
floor. Her urine output remained stable. The differential 
diagnosis also included obstructive pathology as she has a known 
history of nephrolithiasis. We obtained a renal ultrasound did 
not demonstrate any evidence of hydronephrosis. Her creatinine 
return to baseline at the time of her discharge. Initially the 
patient was taken off of her ACE inhibitor and 
hydrochlorothiazide. We resumed her ACE inhibitor at discharge.

#Urinary tract infection: Her urinalysis at time of admission 
showed pyuria, bacteriuria, hematuria. The patient's symptoms 
including lower abdominal pain is consistent with cystitis. She 
had no evidence of systemic infection. The patient was started 
on IV ceftriaxone. The urine culture showed evidence of likely 
to skin contamination. A repeat urinalysis showed improving 
pyuria. At that time the patient had completed 3 days of 
ceftriaxone and we stop the antibiotics.

summary: you or hospitalized for nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain as well as acute renal failure. There is no clear cause for your abdominal symptoms at this time. It is possible that he had a viral infection causing these symptoms. We performed an ultrasound of your liver and gallbladder. He did have evidence of stones within the gallbladder but no signs of infection. The CT scan of her abdomen did not show any acute pathology to cause her symptoms. We treated you with IV fluids and antinausea medications. Your symptoms improved significantly. Your being discharged with a small prescription for the antinausea medications. Use as directed. Your worsening kidney function was likely due to significant dehydration. Your kidney function improved at the time of your discharge.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with PMHx of HTN, HL, CKD stage IV,and reportedly UGIB 
(duodenal s/p resection) presents with bloody diarrhea likely 
from LGIB (hemorrhoidal bleed vs AVM) and ___.  

#Bloody diarrhea: The patient was admitted with abdominal pain 
and four episodes of bright red diarrhea concerning for a lower 
GI bleed. On admission, the patient was hemodynamically stable 
and had a Hct (mid ___, unknown baseline) that was stable 
throught the hospitalization. KUB was notable for mildly dilated 
bowel loops but unremarkable for bowel perforation or 
obstruction. The patient was guaiac negative. Given the 
patient's vascular risk factors, ischemic colitis was initially 
suspected. Lactate was 0.9. The patient was managed 
conservatively with bowel rest, IV fluids, high dose PPI, and 
pain medication. An abdominal CT was performed and no evidence 
of bowel wall thickening or ischemic changes were apparent. 
Given the patient's history of hemorrhoids, the patient's LGIB 
was attributed to hemorrhoidal bleed or AVMs. The patient was 
discharged with plans for followup with his outpatient 
gastroenterologist for possible flexible 
sigmoidoscopy/colonoscopy. At the time of discharge, the 
patient's abdominal pain improved and had no repeat episodes of 
bloody diarrhea. 

# Acute kidney injury: On admission, the patient's Cr was 2.9 
(baseline Cr 1.9-2.3). This was likely secondary to prerenal 
azotemia in the setting of hypovolemia from poor PO intake and 
diarrhea. During this hospitalization, the patient receieved a 
total of 3 L NS. The patient' home irbesartan were held. At the 
time of discharge, the patient's Cr was 1.7 and irbesartan 
restarted.

#Chronic Conditions:

#Dyslipidemia: Patient has a hx of dyslipidemia but was not on a 
statin at the time of admission. Lipid panel during this 
hospitalization was notable for cholesterol:234 and LDL:149. A 
statin was not started 
# HTN: Was stable throughout hospitalization. The patient's home 
irbesartan was for in the setting of ___.
# Asthma: Stable throughout hospitalization. The patient was 
continued on home Flovent.

summary: You were admitted to the ___ because you had abdominal pain and four episodes of bloody diarrhea. At the time of admission your blood pressure and hematocrit levels were found to be normal and stable making a heavy bleed unlikely. An xray of your abdomen showed no bowel perforation but did show dilated bowel loops consistent with slowed bowel movement called an ileus. A CAT scan determined that you do not have any concerning problems with your bowel. You were treated with bowel rest, IV fluids, and pain medication. Given your history of an ulcer, you were also treated with a medication to reduce your stomach acid levels. Your symptoms improved with this regimen. We think you bleeding may have been due to abnormal blood vessels in your colon or hemorrhoids, and you will be scheduled to see a gastroenterologist within 14 days.

Brief Hospital Course:
#Hypokalemia - Attributed to thiazide diuretic therapy, although 
a primary mineralocorticoid state could not be exluded, 
particularly in light of concomitant difficult-to-control 
hypertension and metabolic alkalosis. HCTZ was discontinued. 
Potassium and magnesium were repleted to within the normal range 
prior to discharge. Admission EKG and telemetry did not reveal 
any arrhythmia. The patient will continue on potassium 
supplementation for 3 days after discharge, at which time she 
will have serum potassium and magnesium levels rechecked. She 
has PCP ___ scheduled in 10 days. 
.  
#Chest tightness - There was a low likelihood of suspicion for 
ACS given a TIMI score of zero and spontaneous resolution of the 
symptom without recurrence.  Therefore, inpatient evaluation was 
deferred and the patient was instructed to schedule repeat 
stress testing as an outpatient. Ruled out for MI with serial 
cardiac markers.
.  
#Hypertension - The patient had elevated SBP to 180 mmHg on 
admission. HCTZ was discontinued due to concerns for 
hypokalemia. Amlodipine 10 mg daily was started. Lisinopril was 
increased to 10 mg daily. Atenolol was continued at the 
outpatient dose of 25 mg daily. Renal MRA, although a limited 
exam, did not reveal any evidence of fibromuscular dysplasia, 
renal artery stenosis, or adrenal mass. Chest CTA did not reveal 
coarctation. TSH was WNL. BP was 144/78 taken manually in the 
right arm while seated prior to discharge. The patient would 
likely benefit from additional outpatient workup of an 
underlying cause of her hypertension, such as serum 
renin/aldosterone (for a primary mineralocortoid state, 
particularly in light of hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis) 
and urinary VMA (for pheochromocytoma). 
.
#OSA - BiPAP was prescribed for use while sleeping based on 
sleep medicine recommendations dated ___.
.
#Nutrition - Given a low-sodium diet.

Brief Hospital Course:
Assessment: ___ year old ___ speaking gentleman with a 
history of AVR and a recent dx of cecal mass who presents for 
colonoscopy and biopsy, requiring transition from coumadin to 
heparin.
  
# Cecal mass: The patient has a history of a cecal mass that was 
thought to represent strongyloides based on immunological 
studies and an eosinophilia.  He was previously treated with 
ivermectin empirically and responded, with an eosonophil 
differential that fell from 40% to approximately 10%.  However, 
there was concern that the patient's mass may have represented a 
carcinoma, and hence he was scheduled for a repeat colonoscopy 
to definitely evaluate the mass.  Because of his AVR, he was 
admitted for bridging, though he may have not required admission 
given that his valve is aortic as opposed to mitral, and because 
he has few risk factors, other than his valve, for 
thromboembolism.  The colonoscopy was performed without 
complications and the patient was found to have complete 
resolution of the mass--it was completely absent.  Biopsies were 
taken nonetheless.  The patient was empirically treated with 
another two week course of ivermectin because his eosinophil 
differential was still elevated.  He will follow up with the GI 
and ID clinics.
  
# AVR:  Patient was bridged with heparin and warfarin was 
restarted after the colonoscopy.  After uncovering AHA/ACC data 
that supports the notion that patients with AVR and few risk 
factors do not need a heparin bridge, the patient was d/c'd on 
just warfarin and not lovenox.  He also was instructed to have 
his coags checked two days after discharge.

# HTN: Patient's BP was well controled with toprol and 
lisinopril

summary: You were admitted to the hospital because you were feeling lightheaded. Initially, we thought this might be your heart, however it appears that this was due to the heart failure regimen that you were on being over-aggressive. We gave you some fluids which improved your symptoms, and adjusted your medications slightly in order to stop this from happening again. In particular, we believe that the furosemide (lasix) and metolazone, which are medications that help remove fluid from your body were at too high a dose. In order to stop this from happening again, you should weigh yourself every day in order to help manage your fluid status.
